questions.text: Which scientists were awarded the Nobel Prize for the discovery of insulin?
questions.solution:
Banting and McLeod were awarded the Nobel Prize for the discovery of insulin.

In 1921, Banting took his idea to Professor John Macleod at the University of Toronto, who was a leading figure in the study of diabetes in Canada. Macleod gave Banting a laboratory with a minimum equipments and ten dogs. Banting also got an assistant, a medical student by the name of Charles Best.  

In 1923, the Nobel Committee decided to award Banting and Macleod the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. The decision of the Nobel Committee made Banting furious. He felt that the prize should have been shared between him and Best.

questions.text: For cells of islets of Langerhans, which of the following is correctly matched?
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pair is F-Pancreatic polypeptide. 

Cells of the endocrine pancreas are divided into: 

Cell type

What they secrete

A (alpha)

Glucagon

B (beta)

Insulin and amylin

D (delta)

Somatostatin

F or PP

Pancreatic polypeptide

The close interrelations among these cells allow direct control of secretion of some of the hormones by the other hormones. For example:

  • Insulin inhibits glucagon secretion,
  • Amylin inhibits glucagon secretion, and
  • Somatostatin inhibits secretion of insulin and glucagon.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female is found in a semiconscious state. On initial evaluation, her CBG is 23mg/dL. Her parents tell that the patient is an athlete and was trying to gain weight recently. An evaluation of which of the following will help in establishing a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette strongly suggests hypoglycemia due to surreptitious use of exogenous insulin, characterized by a low C-peptide level.

Insulin abuse is a method for increasing muscle bulk and performance enhancement in athletes, although less common than anabolic steroid abuse. Exogenous insulin does not contain C-peptide. Therefore blood level of C-peptide will be low in such patients. On the other hand, endogenous production of insulin will be characterized by high C-peptide level in blood.

 

Insulin is composed of two chains A and B, and a connecting peptide called C peptide. The insulin and C peptide are packaged in the secretory granules and secreted in equimolar amounts. 

Importance of C-peptide:

  • C peptide is measured by radioimmunoassay, and its level in the blood provides an index of beta-cell function in patients receiving exogenous insulin. If they are unable to produce insulin, they have greatly decreased levels of C peptide.
  • C peptide levels can be used to differentiate between an insulinoma (high C-peptide) and exogenous insulin overdose (low C-peptide) in a patient with hypoglycemia.

questions.text: The half-life of insulin is ______ minutes?
questions.solution:
The half-life of insulin is 4-6 minutes. 

Insulin is degraded by the insulinase enzyme in the liver, and to a lesser extent, in the kidneys and muscles. 

Note: Half-life of C-peptide is 20-30 minutes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic man is initiated on a new hypoglycemic drug whose mechanism of action is extremely similar to the glucose-mediated insulin release mechanism. Which of the following best represents its mode of action?
questions.solution:
Glucose-mediated insulin release occurs through the closure of ATP sensitive K+ channels. Therefore the new drug being initiated is most probably a sulfonylurea which acts via a similar mechanism.

Increased blood glucose concentration is the primary controller of insulin secretion. Inside the beta cells, glucose is converted to glucose-6-phosphate and later ATP is generated. This ATP closes ATP sensitive potassium channels, leading to a rise in K+ and depolarization. This in turn causes the opening of voltage-gated Ca 2+ channels and influx of Ca+. This ultimately leads to the secretion of insulin via exocytosis. 

Diazoxide keeps the ATP sensitive K+ channels open and prevents depolarization, resulting in a decreased insulin release. It is used in patients with insulinoma.

Sulfonylureas cause closure of the ATP sensitive K+ channels, leading to increased insulin secretion. It is used in patients with diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: Insulin mainly facilitates glucose uptake in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Insulin mainly stimulates glucose uptake by skeletal muscles.

Glucose uptake by skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle and adipose tissues is via GLUT-4 which is insulin-dependent. In the presence of insulin, GLUT-4 receptors translocate to the cell membrane and hence, glucose uptake by the cell occurs. 

Most of the other GLUT transporters are not insulin sensitive and are constitutively expressed in the cell membrane. Ex: GLUT-1 in RBCs, brain and kidneys. (GLUT-3 is also present in the brain and kidneys)

Note: Insulin promotes glucose uptake in the liver. However, this is done by increasing the activity of glucokinase and inactivating glycogen phosphorylase. The net effect is the synthesis of glycogen and decreased breakdown of glycogen.

questions.text: Insulin acts on glucose metabolism by______

choices.text: ↓ permeability of glucose across cell membrane
↑ reabsorption of glucose from renal tubules

questions.solution:
Insulin stimulates the glucose entry into the cells via facilitated diffusion by increasing the number of glucose transporters (GLUTs) in the cell membrane.

This type of insulin-dependent glucose transport via GLUT 4 is observed in skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and adipose tissues.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic man develops a gradually increasing demand for exogenous subcutaneous insulin therapy for glycemic control. His current insulin requirement is 130 IU/day. Downregulation of which of the following is associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of insulin resistance, which is characterized by the downregulation of GLUT-4.

GLUT-4 is an insulin-dependent GLUT. Other GLUTs are not insulin sensitive and are constitutively expressed in the cell membrane. 

An arbitrary but clinically useful benchmark considers patients insulin resistant if they require greater than 1 unit/kilogram/day of exogenous insulin to maintain glycemic control. Patients requiring greater than 200 units of exogenous insulin per day are considered severely insulin resistant.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with diabetic ketoacidosis. After the initial evaluation, he is started on intravenous insulin therapy via an infusion pump. He is at increased risk of developing which of the following electrolyte abnormalities?
questions.solution:
In patients who require intravenous insulin therapy, a rapid insulin infusion results in hypokalemia. 

Therefore such patients should undergo serum electrolyte level assessment at frequent intervals while on insulin infusion for prompt diagnosis and early correction of hypokalemia.

Insulin increases the activity of Na-K ATPase in cell membranes so that more K+ is pumped into cells. Hence, serum K+ falls. 

Note: Since insulin decreases serum potassium level, insulin-glucose infusions are used to treat hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Which of the following increases insulin secretion?
questions.solution:
Arginine increases insulin secretion.

Option B: β-adrenergic blockers like propranolol inhibits insulin secretion.

Option C: Epinephrine both stimulates (by beta-adrenergic agonistic action) and inhibits (by alpha-adrenergic agonistic action) the secretion of insulin. However, the inhibitory effect of epinephrine is more dominant than the stimulatory effect.

Option D: Insulin promotes glucose uptake by cells, causing reduced serum K+. Low serum K+ does not cause an increase in insulin secretion. 

Related Pearl: Factors affecting insulin secretion

questions.text: Sympathetic stimulation has the following effect on insulin secretion______
questions.solution:
Sympathetic stimulation inhibits insulin secretion. 

The regulation of insulin secretion can be controlled by alpha-adrenergic mediated response and beta-adrenergic mediated response. The stimulation of alpha-adrenergic receptor (α2) plays an inhibitory role in insulin secretion. On the other hand, the stimulation of beta-adrenergic receptor (β2) plays a stimulatory role in insulin secretion.

Stimulation of the sympathetic nerves to the pancreas releases norepinephrine which predominantly acts on α2-adrenergic receptors, causing a decrease in insulin secretion.

Note: If α-adrenergic receptors are blocked, stimulation of the sympathetic nerves causes increased insulin secretion mediated by β2-adrenergic receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following decreases the secretion of both insulin and glucagon?
questions.solution:
Somatostatin inhibits insulin and glucagon secretion. 

Note: Other actions of somatostatin:

  • Inhibits growth hormone secretion. Somatostatin is also known as growth hormone inhibitory hormone (GHIH).
  • Decreases motility of the stomach, duodenum, and gallbladder.
  • Decreases both secretion and absorption in the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: Insulin secretion is normally stimulated by_____
questions.solution:
Insulin secretion is normally stimulated by GLP-1.

Glucagon-like peptide–1 (GLP-1) and glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide (GIP) are called incretins and are potent stimulators of insulin secretion. They also inhibit glucagon secretion. They are released in the gastrointestinal tract after a person eats a meal. They then cause an “anticipatory” increase in blood insulin in preparation for the glucose and amino acids to be absorbed from the meal. 

Note: Drugs that mimic the action of incretins are used in the management of diabetes.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds antagonizes the action of insulin?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone is a hyperglycemic hormone and antagonizes the effect of insulin.

Hyperglycemic Hormones

  • Glucagon
  • Epinephrine
  • Cortisol
  • Growth hormone
  • Thyroid Hormone

questions.text: In fetus, the insulin secretion begins by _____(months)
questions.solution:
In a fetus, the pancreatic islets are formed in the third month of the fetal life, while insulin secretion begins at about 5th month of fetal life.

The exocrine pancreas starts functioning after birth.

questions.text: How many parts are there in insulin receptor?
questions.solution:
An insulin receptor has 4  parts. It is a tetramer made up of two α and two β subunits.

The α subunits are extracel­lular, whereas the β subunits penetrate through the cell membrane into the cytoplasm.  The intracel­lular portions of the β subunits have tyrosine kinase activity.

Once insulin binds to the alpha subunits, the portions of the beta subunits protruding into the cell become autophosphorylated. Autophosphorylation of the beta subunits, in turn, activates a local tyrosine kinase, which causes phosphorylation of multiple intracellular enzymes. The net effect is to activate some of these enzymes while inactivating others.

Note: IRS: Insulin-receptor substrates, PI3K: Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase.

questions.text: Regarding the action of insulin, which of the following is true?

choices.text: Decreased K+ uptake in adipose tissue

questions.solution:
Insulin decreases ketogenesis in the liver. In the absence of insulin (Type-1 DM), diabetic ketosis may occur.

Effects of insulin on various tissues:

Tissue Increases Decreases
Adipose tissue Increased glucose entry
Increased fatty acid synthesis
Increased glycerol phosphate synthesis
Increased triglycerides deposition
Activation of lipoprotein lipase
Increased K+ uptake		 Inhibition of hormone-sensitive lipase
Muscle Increased glucose entry
Increased glycogen synthesis
Increased amino acid uptake
Increased protein synthesis in ribosome
Increase ketone uptake
Increase K+ uptake

Decrease protein catabolism

Decrease  release of glucogenic amino acids
Liver Increased protein synthesis
Increased lipid synthesis
Increased glycogen synthesis & glycolysis

Decrease ketogenesis

Decreased glucose output due to decreased gluconeogenesis
General Increased cell growth

questions.text: On giving a patient insulin, which of the following is expected to occur first?

choices.text: Increased transport of K+ into adipocytes

questions.solution:
Increased transport of K+ into adipocytes will occur first on giving an injection of insulin. 

Based on time on onset, actions of insulin are classified as:

Rapid (seconds): Increased permeability, leading to:

  • Increased transport of glucose, amino acids, and K+ into insulin sensitive cells

Intermediate (minutes): Changes in activity levels of intracellular enzymes, leading to:

  • Stimulation of protein synthesis
  • Inhibition of protein degradation
  • Activation of glycolytic enzymes and glycogen synthase
  • Inhibition of phosphorylase and gluconeogenic enzymes

Delayed (hours to days): Changed rates of transcription of DNA, leading to: 

  • Increase in mRNAs for lipogenic and other enzymes

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly paired?
questions.solution:
The incorrect pair is thyroxine - decreased blood glucose. Thyroxine is a diabetogenic hormone leading to an increase in blood glucose levels.

Effects Of Hormones On Carbohydrate Metabolism:  

  • Catecholamines: Activation of glycogen phosphorylase and therefore glycogenolysis occurs. Hepatic glucose output is increased, producing hyperglycemia.  
  • Glucocorticoids: Glucocorticoids from the adrenal cortex elevate blood glucose by stimulating gluconeogenesis and inhibiting glucose utilization by the cells.  
  • Growth Hormone: The effects of growth hormone are partly direct and partly mediated via IGF-I (Insulin-like Growth Factor-I). The growth hormone mobilizes FFA from adipose tissue, thus favoring ketogenesis. It decreases glucose uptake into some tissues (“anti-insulin action”), increases hepatic glucose output, and may decrease tissue binding of insulin.

Note: Infusing catecholamine (Epinephrine) mainly promotes glycogenolysis and it is also associated with enhanced rates of aerobic glycolysis in skeletal muscles during exercise (resulting in adenosine triphosphate production).

questions.text: A meal rich in insulin-stimulating amino acids but low in carbohydrates does not cause hypoglycemia because _____

choices.text: Cortisol in the circulation prevents glucose from entering muscle.
Glucagon secretion is also stimulated by the meal.
The amino acids in the meal are promptly converted to glucose.
Insulin does not bind to insulin receptors if the plasma concentration of amino acids is elevated.

questions.solution:
A meal rich in arginine and alanine stimulates both insulin and glucagon secretion. Hence, hypoglycemia does not occur.

Increased blood amino acids stimulate secretion of glucagon, which in turn causes the amino acids to get converted to glucose. So, the mechanism by which hypoglycemia is prevented after a protien rich meal is secretion of glucagon.

questions.text: Which of the following would be least likely seen 14 days after a rat is injected with a drug that kills all of its pancreatic β cells?

choices.text: A rise in the plasma H+ concentration
A rise in the plasma amino acid  concentration
A fall in the plasma amino acid concentration

questions.solution:
A fall is plasma amino acid concentration is least likely to be seen in this case.

Injury to the beta cells of the pancreas impairs insulin production rendering the rat insulin deficient. Due to insulin deficiency, catabolism of proteins increases and amino acids in plasma increase. 

Insulin deficiency increases blood glucose levels, which lead to glycosuria and osmotic diuresis with extracellular dehydration.  There is increase in the plasma osmolality.  

Insulin deficiency causes increased utilization of fats, excess production of ketoacids and metabolic acidosis. Metabolic acidosis - a rise in the plasma H+ develops.

questions.text: Which of the following is an action of insulin?
questions.solution:
Insulin inhibits glucose-6-phosphatase.

Insulin promotes liver uptake, storage, and the use of glucose. After a meal, insulin causes glucose to be rapidly stored in the liver in the form of glycogen. This occurs by: 

  • Inactivation of liver phosphorylase, which is the principal enzyme that causes liver glycogen to split into glucose. 
  • Enhanced uptake of glucose by the liver cells by increasing the activity of the enzyme glucokinase which causes phosphorylation of glucose after it enters the liver cells. Once phosphorylated, the glucose is temporarily trapped inside the liver cells because phosphorylated glucose cannot diffuse back through the cell membrane.
  • Increased activity of enzymes that promote glycogen synthesis, like glycogen synthase.

When insulin levels drop (Ex: Fasting), glucose phosphatase gets activated. This causes phosphate to get detached from glucose phosphate, allowing free glucose from the liver cells to re-enter circulation.

questions.text: A 30 yr old male presents with recurrent attacks of sweating and dizziness. Further workup reveals hypoglycemia, elevated insulin and C-peptide levels. He is diagnosed with insulinoma and given diazoxide. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Opening of the ATP Sensitive K+ channels
Closing of the ATP Sensitive K+ channels
Increase in number of GLUT-4 receptors
Opening of the voltage sensitive Ca2+ channels

questions.solution:
Diazoxide acts by opening ATP sensitive K+ channels and causing a decrease in insulin secretion. 

Glucose enters beta cells of the pancreas via GLUT-2 receptors. Once inside, it is phosphorylated by glucokinase (rate-limiting step) to glucose-6-phosphate which is oxidized to form adenosine triphosphate (ATP). This ATP causes closure of ATP-sensitive potassium channels and hence depolarization. This leads to opening voltage-gated calcium channels and Ca2+ influx. This stimulates fusion of the insulin-containing vesicles with the cell membrane and secretion of insulin into the extracellular fluid by exocytosis. 

Diazoxide keeps the ATP sensitive K+ channels open and prevents depolarization and subsequent insulin release. 

Sulfonylureas cause closure of the ATP sensitive K+ channels, leading to increased insulin secretion.

questions.text: Coma occurs at a glucose level below _____.
questions.solution: Coma occurs when glucose levels fall below 30 mg/dL.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones use receptor tyrosine kinase signalling?
questions.solution:
Insulin uses the receptor tyrosine kinase signalling to exert its functions.

Other hormones acting in a similar fashion includes

  • Growth hormone
  • Growth factors like VEGF, PDGF, FGF, NGF
  • Prolactin
  • Leptin

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens
  Vitamin D
Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

 Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG pathway):
GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin
Cholecystokinin
Oxytocin
Acetylcholine (M1, M3, M5)
cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide
Nitric oxide
2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through the JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) or MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway  Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.
